Setting up access permissions for object type instances
An administrator can restrict users' permissions to work with specific object type instances. The settings determine which users can
create
,
view
,
edit
, and
delete
instances of a particular type.
The primary configuration is performed in the
object type profile
by selecting a
permission control type
in the corresponding attribute.
When creating a new object type with the "Object" [SYS_OBJECT] parent, "System permission control" is set by default. In other cases, the permission control is inherited from the parent type.
When copying an object type, the permission control of the original type is preserved.
The System implements the following permission control types:
Permission Control Type
Description
Recommended Usage Scenario
All users have configured permissions for all instances of the type
Access
to all instances
is determined only by permission settings on the object type related to type instances. Permission differentiation between individual instances is not applied.
Used when there is no need to differentiate permissions between individual object type instances.
All users have read permission
Allows configuring different permissions for
editing
and
deleting
instances. Meanwhile, the permission for
reading
type instances is controlled by access permission settings on the object type.
This permission control type is a combination of "All users have configured permissions for all instances of the type" and "System permission control".
Applied when it’s required to differentiate permissions for
editing
and
deleting
instances, but there’s no need to configure different
read
permissions for different object type instances.
Permission control by condition tree
Allows regulating user permissions for actions performed with type instances (
reading
,
editing
,
deleting
,
creating
), depending on dynamically changing attributes.
Applied when it’s necessary to differentiate permissions to type instances among a large number of users and complex department structures. In this case, conditions can be set using "authorization principals" of any type, including chained ones.
Permission control by assignees
Allows differentiating access to object type instances depending on who is the responsible employee for the business process task. That is, only the
user with an active task
for it will be able to
edit
the routing object profile.
Recommended for use when there is a
business process
triggered by the object type and a need to differentiate permissions according to assigned tasks.
Permission inheritance from related object
Allows differentiating access to instances of the current object type based on access permissions to the
related
object.
To define the related object, specify a
mandatory
object singleselect attribute
in the "Attribute for permission inheritance" field.
Used when
related entities
exist and there is a need to provide
uniform access
to them.
Permission inheritance with system control
Allows differentiating access to instances of the current object type based on access permissions to the
related
object or when configured permissions exist for the object itself.
To define the related object, specify a
mandatory
object singleselect attribute
in the "Attribute for permission inheritance" field.
This permission control type is a combination of "Permission inheritance from related object" and "System permission control".
Used when
related entities
exist and there is a need to provide
uniform access
to them with the possibility of additional configuration of exclusive access to some instances.
By authorization objects
Allows users to restrict actions performed on instances of the main type (
read
,
edit
,
delete
,
create
), depending on the specific values of object attributes used in the type.
Used when it is necessary to configure permissions based on the values of
object attributes
.
System permission control
Allows configuring the ability to
read
,
edit
, and
delete
each instance separately.
Used when it is necessary to differentiate permissions for different instances.
System permission control by group
The principle of operation of "System permission control by group" is similar to that of "System permission control" but is more optimal in terms of performance. Its only difference is that access permissions can be configured only for
access groups
, not for individual users.
Used when it is necessary to differentiate permissions for different instances and there is a large number of users with the same roles (e.g., clients, customers, buyers).
